journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Research on heated-mandrel winding process for resin-matrix composite shells

article-meta.aff: College of Automation, Harbin University of Science and Technology, Harbin, China

author-notes.corresp: M Qiao, Harbin University of Science and Technology, No. 52, Xuefu Road, Nangang District, Harbin, 150080, China Email: chrisjoe0728@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents a new technology named heated-mandrel winding, in which the composite is cured simultaneously while the fiber soaked with resin continuously winds onto a mandrel heated by steam. The thermochemical, cure kinetic, and strain models during the heated-mandrel winding process are established and a numerical simulation program is developed by APDL. The influence of the heating rate, winding speed, and film coefficient on the temperature, curing degree, and strain is researched and analyzed. The effectiveness of the algorithm adopted and the validity of the analytical model and method in this study are experimentally testified. This research provides a theoretical basis and analytical method for the design and parameter optimization of the heated-mandrel winding process.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Resin-matrix composite shells are widely used in the military, in the construction of pressure vessels, in various applications in the fields of aerospace engineering, civil engineering, energy transport, and other fields. This is because these shells have a high specific strength and stiffness, and they can be easily molded and designed, and therefore, they offer significant economic and social benefits.1 The structural performance of the composite shell is highly dependent on the molding process. The molding process directly determines the shell performance and production cost. Nowadays, composite performance and production cost are the main factors affecting the application and development of composite shells.2

Traditionally, the curing of composite shells has usually involved an external heating and curing process in which the shells are cured by heating in a curing oven after the winding operation. The main characteristic of external curing is that the heat from stove heating blocks is transferred to the shell by radiation, conduction, and convection when the shell is heated. The winding process is carried out using a winding machine, and the curing process is carried out in a curing oven. Hence, before starting the curing process, the composite shell needs to be disassembled from the winding machine and installed in the oven. This results in low molding efficiency and high production costs.3 In contrast to the abovementioned traditional method, the winding of the composite can be carried out on the outer surface of the metal mandrel that can then be heated by supplying steam inside the mandrel, and thus, in situ curing can be achieved after the winding operation. Thus, the molding time is reduced and the process is simplified, which directly improves the production efficiency. The author studied the internal-heating curing and molding processes for composite shells. Further, a mathematical model was developed and a finite element method was used to simulate the curing process of composite shell. The author successfully introduced the internal-heating curing process in the manufacture of high-pressure fiber-reinforced plastic pipes.4–7

Once internal-heating curing after winding was realized, the possibility of simultaneous winding and curing was explored. Consequently, a new technology was proposed in which a resin-matrix composite reinforced with fibers is continuously wound over a mandrel, heated by steam, and cured simultaneously. The concept of the heated-mandrel winding process is similar to that of the process for molding fiber-winding thermoplastic composite in which the mandrel is heated using electricity. In both cases, when the mandrel is heated, the heat transfer occurs from the center to the outer surface of the composite. However, unlike the heated-mandrel winding process, no exothermic chemical reaction involving thermoplastic composites occurs during the curing process. This makes the heated-mandrel winding process essentially different from the process of molding fiber-winding thermoplastic composites.8,9 The author studied the heated-mandrel winding process, established a mathematical model of the steam flow field, and performed the numerical simulation of the steam flow and heat transfer during the mandrel-heating process in the previous research.10

The heated-mandrel winding process is a complex interaction process involving heat transfer, resin curing, and changes in the mechanical properties of materials. The curing degree distribution is affected by the temperature distribution because curing is carried out by heating the resin; further, the temperature distribution is affected by the curing degree distribution because resin will release heat when cured. The degree of deformation of materials is affected by the temperature because temperature changes will cause expansion and contraction of materials, and it is also affected by the curing degree because changes in the curing degree will induce curing shrinkage.

Composite shell defects such as dimensional errors and delamination are mostly due to unsuitable temperature variations in the mandrel and uneven curing.5 It is difficult for the traditional experimental method and the trial-and-error method to effectively control the temperature distribution in the curing system. The only way to maintain the uniformity of the temperature in the composite shell is to prolong the curing time, lower the heating rate as much as possible, and increase the frequencies at constant temperature in the curing process in the case of composite shells with thick walls. This approach however results in an increase in production costs. Numerical simulation is adopted to adjust the time and frequency of heating and the constant temperature. Therefore, uniform temperature can be guaranteed and the curing time can be decreased. Also, the time taken to reach the gel point and complete curing can be accurately estimated to avoid incomplete curing or excessive curing. It provides a theoretical basis for optimizing the parameters of the curing process, such as the time and frequency of heating and constant temperature, and curing time, for practical production.

In this paper, the molding principle of heated-mandrel winding is presented. In order to design an efficient heated-mandrel winding process and to improve the forming quality of the shell, it is necessary to research the internal changes occurring in the composite shell and analyze the changes in the properties and the state of the composite. On the basis of the process conditions, structural characteristics, and physicochemical properties of the composite shell, the thermochemical, cure kinetic, and strain models are developed to provide a theoretical basis for the scientific design and optimization of the heated-mandrel winding process. The finite element method is adopted to solve the equations corresponding to the thermochemical model coupled with the cure kinetic model. During the winding process, the fiber is wound onto the mandrel in a layer-by-layer manner. As a result, the mass of the composite shell, temperature loads, and boundary conditions change gradually during the winding process, which makes the simulation process complex. In this study, a solution procedure to simulate the heated-mandrel winding process is developed. The numerical simulation program for the heated-mandrel winding process is developed by using the finite element software ANSYS and the programming language APDL, and the heated-mandrel winding process is numerically simulated. A cylindrical shell is used as an example and is wound to 15 layers at a winding rate of 150 s/layer, a thickness of 8 mm, and a fiber volume fraction of 40%. The law governing the change in temperature, curing degree, and strain with time is analyzed. In order to describe the distribution of the temperature and curing degree clearly, contour plots of the temperature and curing degree are presented. The influence of the heating rate, winding speed, and film coefficient on the temperature, curing degree, and strain is researched. This provides a theoretical basis and analytical method for the design and parameter optimization of the heated-mandrel winding process.

sec.title: The molding principle of heated-mandrel winding
sec.p:
The schematic representation of the molding principle is shown in Figure 1. The mandrel is a hollow axisymmetric metal pipe with uniform wall thickness. A hollow steel pipe with holes on the surface is used for feeding saturated steam, compressed air, and cooling water. It can be seen from the radial section that the holes are distributed symmetrically in the four quadrants. The holes are also distributed evenly in the axial direction. The mandrel rotates around the axis during winding, so the symmetrical hole distribution promotes even steam-flow. The steam used for heating the mandrel is fed into the inner cavity of the mandrel through small holes on the surface of the pipe. The heated mandrel transfers the heat to the fiber and resin layers, and then, the crosslinking curing reaction occurs. The cylinder is rotated so that the cylinder body can be evenly heated and the accumulation of uncured liquid resin at the undersurface of the cylinder because of gravity can be prevented. The molding process is as follows: First, the composite shell is wound to a certain thickness at normal temperature. Then, the gradient elevation of temperature of mandrel is started in order to cure the inner winding layers while winding continues. Heat is continuously transferred from the inner layers to the outer layers of the composite shell, and the outer heated winding layers are cured. Thus, simultaneous winding and curing are achieved. After the composite shell has been wound to the desired thickness, winding is stopped and curing continues until the whole shell is completely cured. Finally, cooling water is fed into the mandrel to cool the shell. Figure 1.
Principle of the heated-mandrel winding process.

The heated-mandrel winding process, which is based on internal-heating curing process, has distinct advantages over other processes, especially in the case of composite shells with thick walls: the quality of molding obtained by adopting this process is high and the process has a high efficiency. This process has the advantages of the internal-heating curing process and the traditional layer-curing process for curing shells with thick walls. Since winding and curing are simultaneously performed, the molding time is significantly reduced in the case of shells with thick walls. Moreover, it benefits the fiber saturation, bubble excretion, and reasonable resin content control. As a result, a significantly compact composite shell with improved mechanical performance is obtained.

sec.title: Modelling of the heated-mandrel winding process
Thermochemical model
sec.p: Heat conduction is affected by changes in the temperature and the curing degree of the composite. The heat from the steam is transferred to the winding layers through the heating mandrel, which causes the exothermic curing reaction of resin, while the heat is simultaneously transferred inside the composite shell.11 By considering a micro-unit of the composite shell for analysis, the following governing equation of the thermochemical model is derived on the basis of thermodynamic heat conduction and energy conservation laws: (1)

Here, ρ, c, and T denote the density, heat capacity, and absolute temperature of the composite, respectively; kx, ky, and kz denote the heat conduction rates corresponding to the x, y, and z directions, respectively; t denotes the time; and Q· denotes heat produced.
The curing reaction occurs in the winding layer of the composite shell, so the last term in equation (1) can be expressed as follows: (2)

Here, ρf and ρr denote the density of fiber and of resin, respectively; vf and vr denote the volume fraction of fiber and of resin, respectively; and Q·f and Q·r denote the heat produced in fiber and resin, respectively, during the curing reaction.
There is no curing reaction for fiber, so equation (2) is expressed as follows: (3)
The resin curing degree is defined as follows: (4)
Here, Qt denotes the heat released by the resin in time t during the curing reaction, and Hr denotes the total heat released by the resin during the whole curing process.
After derivation of equation (4), the following equation is obtained: (5)
According to the above equations, the thermochemical model of the heated-mandrel winding process can be expressed as follows: (6)

sec.title: The cure kinetic model
sec.p: The main factors on which the theoretical basis for the optimization of the curing cycle depends are the speed and mechanism of the curing reaction. During the curing process, the state of the resin changes from a viscous state to a rubber state and finally a vitreous state. Cross-linking reactions occur among the resin molecules, and a net structure is formed. Hence, not only macroscopic changes of the physical state but also microscopic changes of the chemical structure occur during the curing process of thermosetting resin. The changes in the physical state and the chemical structure make the curing mechanism of material systems complex, and this has not been studied thoroughly until now. In practical engineering, a semi-empirical model that does not consider the stoichiometric proportions of the system is adopted as a cure kinetic model.12,13 (7)

The cure kinetic model describes the changes in the curing degree during the curing process. The function f is different for different curing systems. Generally, the cure kinetic model is divided into two types according to different curing mechanisms: one is the nth order reaction model (equation (8)), while the other is an autocatalytic model (equation (9)).12 (8) (9)
Here n and m are curing reaction series and k is the curing reaction rate.
As in a previous study,14 the cure kinetic model adopted in the paper can be expressed as follows: (10)
Here k1 and k2 are the curing rate constants defined by the Arrhenius equation: (11) (12)
Here A1 and A2 are frequency factors; E1 and E2 are activation energies; and R is the universal gas constant.

sec.title: The strain model
sec.p: Expansion and contraction caused by constantly changing the temperature of the composite and curing shrinkage due to the curing of resin result in the generation of strain. Strain significantly affects the mechanical performance of composites and may cause severe deformation or fracture. The reduction of strain is an important issue in the design and optimization of the heated-mandrel winding process. Hence, the strain model is developed to analyze the changes in the strain.

The main factors affecting shell strain are temperature and the curing degree. Strain generated during the curing process of the composite mainly includes thermal strain and curing shrinkage strain.15 Thermal strain is caused by composite deformation, which is induced by constantly changing temperatures.
Suppose that γ is the thermal expansion coefficient of the composite. Then, the thermal strain Δɛth can be expressed as follows: (13)
Chemical shrinkage strain is generated because of volume shrinkage of the composite, which is due to the curing reaction occurring during the heated-mandrel winding process.

A cubic micro-unit of the composite is studied, and the principal strains of the cubic micro-unit generated because of curing shrinkage are denoted as ɛ1, ɛ2, and ɛ3, respectively. Chemical shrinkage Δv is expressed as follows: (14)
Suppose that, generally, the composite shrinks uniformly, that is, ɛ1=ɛ2=ɛ3. Then, the curing shrinkage strain of the composite, Δɛch, can be expressed as follows:16 (15)

The results of our study show that chemical shrinkage Δv is linearly dependent on the curing degree Δα. The linear relationship is Δv=βΔα, where β is the volume shrinkage ratio. Then, the curing shrinkage strain Δɛch can be expressed as follows: (16)
Therefore, the total strain Δɛ is the sum of thermal strain and curing shrinkage strain: (17)

sec.title: Model solution of the heated-mandrel winding process
sec.p: The main mathematical equations of the curing process are the thermochemical and curing kinetic equations, which are partial differential equations. These two equations are coupling equations because of the dependence between temperature and curing degree. Therefore, the value of temperature and curing degree must be determined simultaneously. In order to simulate the curing process accurately, the thermochemical equation is regarded as a transient-heat-conduction equation for an inner heat source, and the finite element method is adopted to solve the equations. During the curing stage, the distribution and changes of the temperature field are not only spatial-domain functions but also time-domain functions. When performing numerical analysis, the heat-conduction equation needs to be discrete in the space and time domains. In this study, the lumped mass technology is adopted to improve the precision and stability of the solution procedure and an adaptive time-step control is adopted to improve the efficiency of the solution.

sec.title: The solution procedure
sec.p:
In the heated-mandrel winding process, the fiber saturated with resin is wound onto the mandrel in a layer-by-layer manner and cured simultaneously. The initial conditions and the boundary conditions for each layer are different during the curing process. The initial conditions of the (n + 1) th layer are the curing results of the nth layer. The radial arrangement of the winding layers over the mandrel is shown in Figure 2. Numerical simulation is performed by supposing that the curing reaction of the resin does not occur during the winding process and that it occurs after the winding operation. After the winding of the first layer is completed, the initial and boundary conditions are set and the curing process of the first layer is simulated. The aim is to determine the transient temperature, curing degree, and strain at each node of this layer. After the winding of the second layer is completed, the initial and boundary conditions are reset and the curing process of the first and second layers as a whole is simulated. The aim is to determine the transient temperature, curing degree, and strain at each node of these two layers. Similarly, the transient temperature, curing degree, and strain at each node of the rest of the layers can be deduced, and the whole shell is numerically simulated after the winding of the last layer is completed. Figure 2.
Radial distribution of the mandrel and winding layers.

In this study, the finite element method is adopted to solve the thermochemical equation coupled with the cure kinetic equation. The inner heat source, Q·, is calculated on the basis of the initial conditions of temperature and curing degree, and the boundary conditions at each node of the model. The transient temperature field is obtained when Q· is substituted into equation (1). The curing degree for this step is calculated on the basis of the transient temperature and the curing degree obtained in the previous step, by adopting the forward-difference formula αn=αn-1+(dα/dt)n-1Δt. The inner heat source Q· of this step is calculated, and then, the temperature field is determined on the basis of Q·. These calculation steps are repeated until the solution is complete. Further, an indirect method is adopted to determine the strain; the temperature field determined from the thermal analysis is applied as the body load to calculate the thermal strain. The chemical shrinkage strain is applied as the initial strain at each calculation step to determine the strain corresponding to that step.

The flow chart of the solution procedure adopted in the numerical simulation of the heated-mandrel winding process is shown in Figure 3. The detailed solution procedure is as follows:
Set the current winding layer number n = 1 and current load step = 1 before thermal analysis.
In the preprocessing step, define the analysis type, element type, physical parameters, and curing kinetic parameters of the material, and the development of the finite element model of the shell.
Apply the boundary conditions for the thermal analysis to the finite element model of the shell.
Solve the distribution of the temperature field and the curing degree field for this load step by using equations (6) and (10) according to the curing cycle and save the results in the respective files.
Consider the next load step and repeat the steps 3–5 until the desired time.
Perform winding to form the next winding layer, and repeat the steps 2–6 until the desired number of winding layers are obtained.
Set loadstep=1.
Delete the thermal load of the shell and change the analysis type from thermal analysis to structural analysis. Define the thermal expansion coefficient and volume shrinkage ratio applied to calculate the strain.
Apply the boundary conditions for structural analysis.
On the basis of the results obtained in step 4, calculate the thermal strain and curing shrinkage strain to determine the total strain of this load step, and then save the strain results.
Consider the next load step, and repeat the steps 9–11 until total time when the curing is completed.
Perform postprocessing of the results of temperature field, curing degree field, and strain field, according to requirements.
Figure 3.
Flow chart of the solution procedure adopted in the numerical simulation of the heated-mandrel winding process.

sec.title: Initial conditions and boundary conditions
sec.p: Initial conditions and boundary conditions need to be determined to solve the governing equation.
The initial conditions of the heated-mandrel winding process are set as follows: at the initial time t0, the initial temperature T0=30°C, initial curing degree α0=0, and initial strain ɛ0=0. (18)

The boundary conditions for each fiber winding layer need to be set independently because they are different for each layer. The boundary conditions are expressed in equations (19)–(22) (1≤n≤nmax). (19) (20) (21) (22)

Here n denotes the winding layer number; nmax, the total winding layer number; f(t), the curing cycle; Tm, the inner surface temperature of the mandrel; Tin, the inner surface temperature of the nth winding layer; Ton, the outer surface temperature of the nth winding layer; and Tln and Trn, the left- and right-end surface temperatures of the nth winding layer, respectively.

sec.title: Algorithm verification
sec.p:
Bogetti and Gillespie analyzed the curing process of thick section components.17 The algorithm adopted in this study is validated by comparing the results of this study with those of the study conducted by Bogetti and Gillespie. In their study, the material system is glass/polyester. The thermal property parameters of the composite are listed in Table 1, and the cure kinetic parameters are listed in Table 2. The size of the laminate is 15.24 cm × 15.24 cm × 2.54. Its chemical kinetics model is expressed as follows: (23) Table 1.
Thermal properties of glass/polyester
Density (kg/m3) Specific heat (KJ/kg·°C) Thermal conductivityk3 (KW/m·°C) Thermal conductivity ratio (k1/k3)
1.89×103 1.26 2.163×10-4 2
Table 2.
Cure kinetic parameters of glass/polyester
m n k0(s-1) ΔEc(J/mol) Hr(kJ/kg)
0.524 1.476 6.1667×1020 1.674×105 77.5

The comparison between the temperature distribution obtained by performing numerical simulation and that based on experimental results corresponding to the center point of the laminate is shown in Figure 4. The numerical simulation results agree well with the test data presented in literature, which confirms the validity of the analytical model and method. Figure 4.
Comparison between simulation results and experimental results.

sec.title: Numerical simulation of heated-mandrel winding process
Finite element modelling
sec.p: The ratio of the axial length to the radial thickness is large for the cylindrical shell. Temperature changes in the axial direction have little influence on the distribution of temperature and curing degree, as was established in previous research.18 Hence, a two-dimensional axisymmetric finite element model of the cylindrical shell is established, with the influence of temperature changes in the axial direction being neglected. The shell selected is composed of 15 layers and the radial thickness of the whole model is 8 mm. The modelling method is as follows: First, the two-dimensional axisymmetric geometric model of the shell is established. The x axis of the model is in the radial direction of the shell, and the y axis is in the axial direction. The element type is PLANE55, which is a 2-D thermal solid element with four nodes provided by ANSYS. Second, the established geometric model is meshed. The first layer of the model is divided into five elements in the radial direction and four elements in the axial direction. Thus, the first layer is divided into 20 elements and 30 nodes. The modelling method for the subsequent layers is the same as that used for the first layer, with each layer being divided into 20 elements. The whole shell is therefore divided into 200 elements and 255 nodes.

The nodes observed are selected according to the requirements. In this paper, four nodes are selected. Node number 9 is located at the center of the outer surface of the first layer, node number 117 at the center of the outer surface of the 5th layer, node number 238 at the center of the outer surface of the 10th layer, and node number 17 at the center of the inner surface of the first layer. Node number 17 is used to determine the temperature history of the mandrel for the shells. The locations of the four nodes to be researched are shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Finite element model of the shell and locations of the nodes to be investigated.

sec.title: Parameters for simulation
sec.p:
In this investigation, the material system is glass/epoxy. Thermal properties and cure kinetic parameters of the materials and other parameters for simulation are listed in Tables 3–5.19 Table 3.
Thermal property parameters of glass/epoxy
Material Density (kg/m3) Heat capacity (J/(kg·°C)) Heat conduction coefficient (W/(m2·°C)) Volume fraction (%)
Glass 2600.0 690.0 0.270 40
Epoxy 1200.0 7900.0 8.65 60
Table 4.
Cure kinetic parameters of glass/epoxy
M n A1 (s–1) A2 (s–1) ΔE1 (J/mol) ΔE2 (J/mol) Hr (J/kg)
0.839 1.159 1.76 × 105 3.901 × 105 6.498 × 104 5.399 × 104 7.02 × 105
Table 5.
Other parameters for simulation
Environmental temperature (°C) Initial temperature (°C) Initial time (s) Number of inflexions in curing cycle Film coefficient (W/(m2·°C))
30 30 0 7 8.0

sec.title: Temperature history of the shells
sec.p:
The temperature history of the mandrel adopted in this paper consists of seven changes and is divided into three stages, as shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Curing system for the shell showing seven stages of heating and cooling.

The first stage: The preheating stage is represented by steps (1) and (2). During this stage, the temperature of the material increases evenly, the resin viscosity decreases, and the fiber is well saturated. No drastic curing reaction occurs during this stage, and therefore, the heating rate could be slightly high. A gel reaction occurs during the holding process; however, the temperature at this stage is low and a chemical reaction occurs only for active large groups. Linear molecules combine with each other to form a jelly.

The second stage: The rising temperature stage is depicted by steps (3)–(6). During this stage, the reaction continues to occur for the gelled resin. Because the temperature is high, cross-linking reactions occur for active groups that do not react at the previous stage, to form a three-dimensional network structure. During the holding process, the resin is fully cured and the performance of the shells is guaranteed.

The third stage: The cooling stage is depicted by step (7). At this point, the shells demold and release some strain, and a gap is generated between the shell and the mandrel because of unsynchronized shrinkage with the decrease in the temperature. The cooling rate cannot be too high; otherwise, it could cause deformation of the shells and affect their quality.

sec.title: Results of numerical simulation of the heated-mandrel winding process
sec.p:
In order to describe the distribution of the temperature and curing degree clearly, contour plots of the temperature and curing degree fields at various times are shown in Figure 7. On the left are the contour plots of the temperature fields and on the right are the contour plots of the curing degree fields. The corresponding winding layer numbers for the above time points are 2, 4, 6, 10, 12, and 15 layers. Time points from (a) to (f) shown below are inflections of the temperature rising stage and holding stage, while those from (g) to (j) correspond to the cooling stage. Figure 7.
Cloud charts of temperature and curing degree at different times.

The curing degree of the nodes is small at 300 s. The temperature of the innermost layer is the highest where the curing degree of the nodes is the largest; however, the value is only 0.004682. The curing degree is so small that it is not enough to cause the curing reaction of the resin. The temperature changes are therefore all caused by heat transfer. The nodes of the innermost layer begin to be cured at 600 s. As the temperature rises, the number of cured nodes increases; the heat released by the curing reaction also increases. The heat generated causes a further increase in the temperature. The curing of all nodes of the first layer is completed when the time reaches 1500 s. At this point, the temperature of the outer surface of the first winding layer is about 76.801°C and that of the 8th winding layer is about 67.877°C. With the temperature rising gradually and the curing reaction continuing, each layer is cured in turn. As shown in Figure 7, the winding of 15 layers is completed at 2250 s. At this point, the first 11 winding layers are cured but the last 4 are not. Although the period from 2250 to 2400 s corresponds to the cooling stage, the mandrel temperature is higher than the shell temperature. The temperature of the outer layer of the shell gradually rises under the influence of the heat transferred from the mandrel and released by the curing reaction of the resin. Thereafter, the mandrel temperature gradually falls below the shell temperature. A characteristic feature of the temperature distribution of the shell is that the temperature of the outer layers is higher than that of the inner layers. When the time reaches 2700 s, the mandrel temperature is lowered to room temperature and the temperature of the outer surface of the shell is still about 103.45°C.

To summarize the observations, the temperature of the inner layers of the shell is higher than that of the outer layers, and the curing degree of the inner layers is greater than that of the outer layers during the winding process from 0 to 2250 s. Heat transfer occurs from the center to the outer surface of the shell, and the shell is cured from the inner layers to the outer layers in a layer-by-layer manner. Parts of the nodes of the outer layers are still not cured at 2250 s, which is the end of the temperature rising stage. At this point, the mandrel temperature is higher than that of the shell, and curing reaction rejects heat, so these parts of the nodes can be cured even in the cooling stage. After all the nodes are completely cured, the temperature of the nodes of the outer layers gradually increases beyond that of the inner layers.

In order to observe the changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time, representative node numbers 9, 113, and 238, which are located in the 1st, 5th, and 10th layer, respectively, are selected as research objects. The locations of these three nodes on the model are shown in Figure 5. The changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time are shown in Figures 8, 9, and 10, respectively. Figure 8.
Temperature history of the nodes. Figure 9.
Curing degree history of the nodes. Figure 10.
Strain history of the nodes.

Figure 8 shows the changes in temperature with time for nodes 9, 113, and 238 during the whole process of the heated-mandrel winding. The temperature gradually increases during the winding process and then decreases after the curing is completed. As shown in Figure 8, temperature changes manifest as a serrated profile, and the serration decreases gradually. This is because the temperature of the observed nodes is high when they are cured, but the initial temperature of the nodes of the new winding layers is only 30°C; therefore, under the influence of heat transfer, the temperature of the observed nodes decreases as the winding continues. New nodes occur farther and farther away from the observed nodes, and the influence of the temperature of the new nodes on that of the observed nodes decreases more and more. This results in a decrease in the serration.

Figure 9 shows the changes in the curing degree of nodes 9, 113, and 238 during the whole process of the heated-mandrel winding. The common characteristic feature of these three curves is that the curing degree is small at first, and it subsequently increases sharply. When the curing degree reaches 1.0, it remains constant. This is because initially, the temperature of the nodes is low and the curing reaction rate is low, which leads to a small curing degree. As the temperature gradually increases to a certain value, it induces the rapid curing of the resin, which sharply increases the curing degree. Curing is complete when the curing degree reaches 1.0. As shown in Figure 9, the inner layer is cured first, but this curing rate is the lowest. The outer layer is cured last, but this curing rate is the highest.

Figure 10 shows the changes in the strain of nodes 9, 113, and 238 during the whole process of the heated-mandrel winding. The temperature and curing degree are the main factors influencing the strain. When the curing degree either does not reach 0.1 or exceeds 0.9, the strain changes with the temperature. This is because the curing reaction rate is low at these points and curing shrinkage because of changes in the curing degree is small; therefore, the strain is mainly influenced by the temperature changes. The strain changes with the temperature according to thermal expansion and contraction. At the rapid curing stage, the strain shows a downtrend. This is because curing shrinkage plays a leading role during this stage.

sec.title: Influence of technology parameters on heated-mandrel winding process
sec.p: Technology parameters such as heating rate, winding speed, and film coefficient affect the heated-mandrel winding process, molding quality, and production efficiency of the shell. The influence of the parameters on the heated-mandrel winding process is determined by observing the simulation results of the changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time under different conditions. This provides an analytical basis for the design and optimization of the heated-mandrel winding process. The influence of the heating rate, winding speed, and film coefficient on the temperature, curing degree, and strain is analyzed on the basis of the developed model and initial conditions. Node 9, located in the first winding layer, is selected as the research object.

sec.title: Influence of heating rate
sec.p:
Figure 11 shows the changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time for node 9 at the heating rates of 15°C/5 min, 30°C/5 min, and 60°C/5 min in the second temperature rising stage. The higher the heating rate, the higher is the curing reaction rate; however, the fluctuation in the temperature and strain is greater. It is easy to generate a large gradient in the temperature and strain, which results in uneven curing and incorrect physical dimensions. If the heating rate is decreased, it will reduce the fluctuation in the temperature and strain but will prolong the curing time and reduce the molding efficiency. Figure 11.
Curves showing the influence of different heating rates on (a) temperature, (b) curing degree, and (c) strain.

sec.title: Influence of winding speed
sec.p:
Figure 12 shows the changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time for node 9 at the winding speeds of 80 s per layer, 150 s per layer, and 210 s per layer, respectively. The higher the winding speed, the smaller is the gradient of the temperature and strain and the shorter is the heating time of the winding layers. Further, winding layers are heated insufficiently in short time, and the temperature of the winding layers is low, which results in low curing reaction rates. If the winding speed is decreased, the curing reaction rate will be improved, but the gradient of the temperature and strain is increased, which would decrease the molding quality of the shell. Figure 12.
Curves showing the influence of different winding speeds on (a) temperature, (b) curing degree, and (c) strain.

sec.title: Influence of film coefficient
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the changes in the temperature, curing degree, and strain with time for node 9, whose film coefficients are 4.0, 8.0, and 16.0 W/m2°C, respectively. The smaller the film coefficient the higher the temperature of the nodes and the curing reaction rate. This is because as the temperature decreases because of air convection, the film coefficient and heat dissipating capacity decrease while the temperature and curing reaction rate increase. However, the decrease in the temperature increases the strain, and the shell quality is affected simultaneously. If the film coefficient is increased, the strain will decrease, but the curing reaction rate will be affected. Figure 13.
Curves showing the influence of different film coefficients on (a) temperature, (b) curing degree, and (c) strain.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the heated-mandrel winding process is presented. The thermochemical, cure kinetic, and strain models of the composite shell are developed in this study. A numerical simulation program for the heated-mandrel winding process is developed by using the finite element software ANSYS and the programming language APDL. The heated-mandrel winding process is numerically simulated using the finite element method.

The following conclusions have been obtained from the numerical simulation of the heated-mandrel winding process.
The law governing the change in temperature, curing degree, and strain with time is analyzed. Based on the simulation, the temperature changes of observed nodes appear to be serrated, and the serration decreases gradually. The inner layer is the first to be cured, but the curing rate is the lowest; in contrast, the outer layer is cured last, but has the highest curing rate. The strain changes with temperature when the curing degree either does not reach 0.1 or exceeds 0.9. At the rapid curing stage, the strain shows a downtrend, which is due to curing shrinkage playing a leading role during this stage.
The influence of the heating rate, winding speed, and film coefficient on the temperature, curing degree, and strain was investigated. The simulation results show that the higher the heating rate, the higher is the curing reaction rate; however, the greater is the fluctuation in the temperature and strain. The higher the winding speed, the smaller is the gradient of the temperature and strain; however, the shorter is the heating time of the winding layers and the lower is the curing reaction rate. The smaller the film coefficient, the higher is the temperature of the nodes, curing reaction rate, and the greater is the strain.
